title: Case Study Content Gaps — Problem Statement & Data Request
description:
Several comments from document review (Feb 2026) identify missing or weak content in the Metro Cable case study sections, particularly around problem statement development and data requests.

## 1. Word Cloud — Replace with Table (Comment [115] — Deniz Oker)
**Location:** Lesson containing the word cloud visualization
The current word cloud is described as 'very confusing and disorganized.' Replace with a table or structured alternative that presents the same information more clearly.

## 2. Problem Statement — Show 7-Element Evaluation First (Comment [121] — Deniz Oker)
**Location:** Metro Cable problem statement section
The Metro Cable case study jumps straight to the boiled-down problem statement. The initial problem statement was actually derived from evaluation across the 7 elements (as shown in slide 12 of the PPT). Add slide 12's content/visual before the final problem statement to show the step-by-step thinking process.

## 3. Problem Statement Refinement Process Flow (Comment [122] — Deniz Oker)
**Location:** Section introducing iterative problem statement refinement
Add a process flow showing how an initial problem statement is iteratively refined until reaching the final list of ops. This should visualize the iterative refinement steps.

## 4. Data Request — Add Risks & Considerations (Comment [131] — Deniz Oker)
**Location:** 05-data-request-and-ingestion.mdx — 'The Formal Data Request' section
Add risks and considerations for data requests, sourced from slide 19 of the playbook PPT.

## 5. Metro Cable Data Request — Add Example List (Comment [132] — Deniz Oker)
**Location:** 05-data-request-and-ingestion.mdx — 'Metro Cable Example – Initial Data Request' section
Add a concrete example data request list for the Metro Cable case study, sourced from slide 18 of the PPT. Currently this section lacks an actual example.

title: Pull PPT Graphics into Course Lessons
description:
Multiple comments from document review (Feb 2026) request that graphics from the PowerPoint deck be integrated into corresponding course lessons. All slides referenced are from the AOMT Playbook PPT.

## Graphics to Add

### Slide 5 → 04-introducing-aomt.mdx (Comments [93] Deniz, [94] Paul)
Add the concept graphic from slide 5 of the playbook PPT to the 'Introducing AI Enabled Problem-Solving' lesson. Paul noted 'this or something better' is acceptable.

### Slide 6 → 05-playbook-structure.mdx (Comments [102] Deniz, [103] Paul)
Replace the current bullet-point list in the Playbook Structure lesson with the visual from slide 6. Both reviewers agreed the visual is cleaner and more effective.

### Slide 10 → Core Activities process flow (Comment [112] Deniz)
The current process flow looks linear/waterfall. Replace with the circular/iterative graphic from slide 10, which better represents the non-linear nature of the methodology.

### Slide 11 → 03-problem-statement.mdx (Comment [119] Deniz)
Replace the bullet list of Problem Statement elements (Timeframe, etc.) with the visual graphic from slide 11.

### Slide 15 → Issue Tree section (Comment [125] Deniz)
Add an example issue tree for the Metro Cable case study, sourced from slide 15 of the PPT. The current section references an issue tree but shows no visual example.

## Action Required
Export or adapt the relevant slides from the PowerPoint deck and integrate as images or structured components in the MDX lessons.

title: Navigation & Progress Indicators
description:
Two structural UX improvements identified during document review (Feb 2026).

## 1. Breadcrumb / Progress Indicator (Comment [117] — Deniz Oker)
**Location:** All section/lesson pages
It is not clear to the reader which stage/activity they are currently on. Add a breadcrumb or visual progress clue that shows location within sections, chapters, topics, and steps on every page.
Example mockup was referenced but not attached — coordinate with design for implementation.

## 2. Simplify Summary TOC Entry (Comment [26] — Paul Giessler)
**Location:** Table of Contents / course navigation
The Playbook Summary section spans only part of one page. The sub-section breakdown in the TOC is unnecessary at that scale — collapse it to a single 'Summary' item rather than listing sub-sections.
